intro: Sabatia tuberculata, commonly known as the wooly pimpernel, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It is a member of the Geraniaceae family and is characterized by its hairy, glandular leaves and showy, pink to red flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, sandy soils in open woodlands and prairies. It blooms from June to September, producing small, clustered inflorescences. Sabatia tuberculata is often found in disturbed habitats and is considered a characteristic species of the southeastern United States.
